awd_titl_txt: Southernmost Patagonia: The Connection Between Magmatism, Subduction Zone, Slab Window and Sub-continental Mantle Lithosphere
awd_abstract_narration:
The Earth's mantle represents approximately 82% by volume and 68% by mass of the Earth, and therefore, it influences the movement of tectonic plates, earthquakes and volcanism on the surface.  A fundamental step to understand the composition and nature of the Earth's mantle from the study of basaltic lavas (partial melts of the mantle) is to establish the budget and distribution of volatiles (hydrogen, carbon, fluorine, chlorine, sulfur) in the Earth's interior. Volatiles influence mantle melting, magma crystallization, magma migration and volcanic eruption, and their abundances and spatial distribution provide important constraints on models of mantle flow and temperature. Moreover, volatiles are key constituents of the Earth's atmosphere and oceans and, thus, constraining the cycling of volatiles between the Earth's interior and surface is of fundamental importance to understand the long-term evolution of our planet, as they fundamentally affect plate tectonics, climate, and habitability. The project will support an African-American female graduate student, an Indian research scientist and a Hispanic Professor at Brown University. It promotes the collaboration with geochemists from nine institutions from three different countries: USA, Argentina and Chile, and will enhance the infrastructure for research and education at Brown University, Oregon State University and Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution.  Communication of results will occur through: 1) peer-reviewed journals, presentations at conferences and invited university lectures, 2) hands-on science learning activities for local elementary and high school classes, and 3) outreach to the general audience through public lectures.

Diverse hypotheses have been proposed for the origin of the magmatism in southern Patagonia, from flux melting of the mantle wedge during devolatilization of the subducted Nazca and Antarctic plate, to adiabatic decompression melting of a carbonated and hydrous asthenosphere upwelling through the slab window, to melting of a volatile-rich metasomatized subcontinental lithospheric mantle. All proposed hypotheses invoke the role of volatiles. Surprisingly, data on the volatile contents of basalts and mantle xenoliths from this region are non-existent. This is a glaring omission from the geochemical data given the importance of volatiles. The focus of this study will be to examine the regional and temporal variations in volatile contents and microstructure of geochemically well-characterized Eocene-recent basalts and associated mantle xenoliths co-located with the seismic array from southern Patagonia. The lavas and their xenoliths in this region represent smaller melt volumes tapped locally from areas lacking steady-state magma chambers, experience relatively less mixing and differentiation, and offer the best opportunity to determine the composition, lithology and volatile contents of the mantle sources. The integration of these geochemical and microstructural data to a previously funded seismic experiment will enable better constraints on the temperature, composition, viscosity and density structure of the mantle beneath southern Patagonia.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The fundamental goal of our research is to understand the interactions between subduction processes and the evolution of the continental lithosphere through the interpretation of a well-integrated set of geochemical data of lavas erupted in southern Patagonia. We want to use this region, affected by the subduction of the Chile ridge and formation of a slab window, as a model to investigate the various processes that make up the subduction-continent system and their interdependent co-evolution. 

The lavas in this region represent smaller melt volumes tapped locally from areas lacking steady-state magma chambers, they experience relatively less mixing, differentiation and crustal contamination, and offer the best opportunity to determine the composition/lithology of their mantle sources and the conditions of magma generation. An important objective of the project is to test previous geodynamic models of mantle flow beneath southern Patagonia. The integration of our geochemical data to the already existing seismic experiment will allow us to constrain the composition and flow of the mantle beneath southern Patagonia.

During the period of this project, we analyzed 234 samples for whole rock major and trace element contents, with a subset of 131 samples also analyzed for radiogenic isotopes of Strontium, Neodymium, Lead and Hafnium of which 97 samples have eruption ages determinations.

Our results indicate the presence of four distinct mantle components: A subduction-influenced component, a depleted component typical of the south Atlantic basin mantle, and two enriched components typical of the Discovery and Bouvet hotspot.

There is a temporal variation in the geochemistry of southern Patagonia lavas that points to variation in mantle composition and conditions of mantle melting. The older volcanism (~3-12 Ma) is characterized by the presence of interspersed subduction-influenced and the south Atlantic mantle components, whereas the younger volcanism (< 3 Ma) indicates the existence of enriched mantle compositions akin those of the Discovery and Bouvet hotspots. Furthermore  there is a clear  decrease in extent and an increase in depth of mantle melting   as the age of lava eruptions become younger.

Although we do not see significant spatial geochemical variation among older lavas (~3-12 Ma), there is a spatial variation in the composition of the young basaltic volcanism (< 3 Ma);  with northern lavas carrying the Discovery-type mantle component, whereas the southern lavas point to a Bouvet-type mantle component. Furthermore, our results suggest that the melting of the sub-continental lithospheric mantle has played a significant role on the composition of the younger volcanism (< 3 Ma)  suggesting an spatial variation in the composition of the subcontinental lithospheric mantle.

The composition of the southern Patagonia lavas is consistent with an older volcanism (~3-12 Ma) indicating the presence of a south Atlantic mantle affected by the subduction of the Nazca plate, and a young volcanism (< 3 Ma) pointing to the contribution of the sub-continental lithospheric mantle that was affected by a very recent (≤150 Ma) percolation of melts with Discovery (to the North) and Bouvet (to the South) compositions during the opening of the Atlantic basin.

In contrast to geodynamic models that suggest the presence of Pacific mantle beneath southern Patagonia within the area of the slab window, the composition of the southern Patagonia basaltic volcanism is consistent with a South Atlantic mantle influenced by the Shona, Discovery, and Bouvet hot-spots. 

We propose that within the region of the slab window in southern Patagonia the sub-continental lithospheric mantle has been eroded and incorporated into the mantle that is flowing westward from South America toward the Pacific basin across the slab window. Our proposed model is consistent with recent seismological information and global navigation satellite system (GNSS) results indicating that the southern Patagonia within the slab window area has lost most of its sub-continental lithospheric mantle. It is also consistent with the orientation of the mantle flow based on seismic azimuthal anisotropy, but our data predicts the opposite direction of mantle flow compared to geodynamic mantle flow models. This is a surprising result that is forcing us to reevaluate the consensus geodynamic models presented for slab windows worldwide. 

This project fundamentally contributed to the education and career development of a female African-American graduate student and a male undergraduate student. It  provided an engaging research experience in solid-earth geochemistry. Moreover, it reinforced collaborations with other national and international scientist and institution and supported the analytical facilities at Brown University and Washington State University.
